comments.html:
While my inner networking geek agrees with you (and I was proposing this very idea in at least one blog post), the harsh reality disagrees with us:

A) You'd lose the summarization property of IP subnets, which might haunt you in very large networks;

B) I don't think the network or server admins would be happy to run a routing protocol (apart from BGP) between servers and routers.

As for BGP, at least one of my customers runs BGP between server loopback and L3 switches ... have to write about that one day.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: In an overlay virtual networking environment, where the hypervisor sends all traffic from a single IP address, why not do L3 all the way through, and treat each server as a router, and use the router loopback address as the endpoint IP for tunnels?
